line: TESLA’S PROBLEM: OVERESTIMATING AUTOMATION, UNDERESTIMATING HUMANS | Elon Musk's Tesla has serious
label: paragraph

line: production problems
label: paragraph

line: T esla was hoping to produce 5,000 new Model 3 electric cars each week in 2018. So far, it has
label: paragraph

line: failed to manufacture even half that number. Questioned on the matter, the company’s CEO, Elon
label: paragraph

line: Musk, claimed that “excessive automation was a mistake” and that “humans are underrated”.
label: paragraph

line: He’s not wrong – the recent drive for full automation has overlooked the importance of adaptability.
label: paragraph

line: Humans are still far more able to adapt to change than artificial intelligence (AI). In the long-term, AI
label: paragraph

line: has the potential to replace human workers, but for now leaders need to determine the right speed
label: paragraph

line: of change.
label: paragraph

line: The Tesla factory in Silicon Valley is highly automated. Early on, Musk understood that any process
label: paragraph

line: following a sequence of predefined steps and taking place on a fairly controlled environment, such
label: paragraph

line: as a factory floor, could be automated by artificial intelligence and robots. And this is something he
label: paragraph

line: should be credited for.
label: paragraph

line: But while autonomous systems are developing rapidly, humans remain far better at adapting to
label: paragraph

line: unforeseen changes. When it comes to complex factory work, this is something that should not be
label: paragraph

line: underestimated. Looking back on Tesla’s productivity issues, Musk undoubtedly missed the
label: paragraph

line: importance of adaptability in manufacturing. The probability of small errors and unforeseen
label: paragraph

line: situations is proportional to the complexity of the process, especially when the process takes place
label: paragraph

line: in the physical world.
label: paragraph

line: Adaptive intelligence
label: heading

line: Humans and other forms of intelligent life evolved to survive in a constantly changing world. For this
label: paragraph

line: reason, they can cope remarkably well with unforeseen situations and discrepancies between
label: paragraph

line: expected and actual events. As cognitive scientist Gary Marcus emphasises, there are a lot of
label: paragraph

line: things “that go into human intelligence, like our ability to attend to the right things at the same time,
label: paragraph

line: to reason about them to build models of what’s going on in order to anticipate what might happen
label: paragraph

line: next and so forth.”
label: paragraph

line: Humans and animals can also adapt their bodies to radically different situations in order to achieve
label: paragraph

line: their goals. For example, we can move forward by walking, swimming, jumping, climbing and
label: paragraph

line: crawling – and we can do so even if we lose the use of a limb. These dynamic aspects of biological
label: paragraph

line: systems help them cope with radical change under highly complex situations.
label: paragraph

line: Machine learning, on the other hand, is not yet at the level of human intelligence and adaptability.
label: paragraph

line: Sure, we have made great progress. Today, advanced AI algorithms, inspired by nervous systems,
label: paragraph

line: can learn to recognise similar situations like a traffic light turning red or a ball falling on the street
label: paragraph

line: even better than humans. Developments in robotics also mean that new robots made of soft
label: paragraph

line: materials can physically adapt to unforeseen objects in the physical environment. But in both cases,
label: paragraph

line: adaptability is limited to variations within a restricted category of objects or events.
label: paragraph

line: The truth is that we have not yet mastered the design of robots and AI that are resilient enough to
label: paragraph

line: respond to unpredictable environments. Take the example of robots used in the packaging industry.
label: paragraph

line: Automated guided vehicles with limited on-board intelligence can only follow simple programming
label: paragraph

line: instructions taking them along fixed routes in a defined environment. These robots might be able to
label: paragraph

line: pick up a product and place it into a carton, without the ability to do anything more complex. When
label: paragraph

line: the job changes, the robot will have to be replaced.
label: paragraph

line: More complex mobile robots are also in use. They have built-in sensors and scanners, as well as
label: paragraph

line: software that allows them to detect their surroundings and choose the most efficient route so that a
label: paragraph

line: product is not necessarily placed in the same location every time. These more complex robots are
label: paragraph

line: more flexible and adaptable, but they are still quite far away from what biological systems can do.

label: paragraph

line: production problems
label: paragraph

line: T his could be a problem for overly automated factories where small physical discrepancies (a
label: paragraph

line: broken wheel, wear and tear on the ground, imprecisely positioned parts) can rapidly accumulate
label: paragraph

line: and result in unpredictable situations (a component is not where it should be, a robot is missing).
label: paragraph

line: When a process changes or the factory starts making a new product, then there is a need to
label: paragraph

line: reconfigure the equipment and find a different solution. This is not yet entirely within reach of AI and
label: paragraph

line: robotics.
label: paragraph

line: Full automation
label: heading

line: Musk has publicly noted his desire to create a fully autonomous factory. His underlying goal is to
label: paragraph

line: overcome the limits of human speed. With greater speed, higher outputs can be achieved. But in
label: paragraph

line: complex environments, such as a highly automated factory, there is a need for highly adaptable
label: paragraph

line: robots that can respond to unforeseen situations and to each other like biological systems do.
label: paragraph

line: Introducing that sort of biological resilience in robotics and AI requires further research.
label: paragraph

line: The first involves testing robotic automation within a defined set of processes, such as picking raw
label: paragraph

line: material and placing it on the assembly line. The second involves expanding that test to multiple
label: paragraph

line: functions and processes, such as combining the raw material and packaging the product. The third
label: paragraph

line: stage is to deploy robotic co-workers and adaptive AI as human assistants. Today, this is the best
label: paragraph

line: we can aim for.
label: paragraph

line: It is not yet clear when we will have the technology for full automation without human intervention
label: paragraph

line: (stage four) and what form it will take but Musk should be praised for trying. He may have
label: paragraph

line: underestimated humans but what he is learning is precious and will help him to drive ahead of
label: paragraph

line: others in the future.
